page.title: Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda link allegations timeline

revisions.rev:
{{Longish|date=August 2010}} This article is a chronological listing of allegations of meetings between members of [[al-Qaeda]] and members of [[Saddam Hussein]]'s government, as well as other information relevant to [[conspiracy theories]] involving [[Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda]]. Opinions of experts on this subject are that not all of the specific claims about meetings can be substantiated with evidence and that the evidence that does exist leads to the conclusion that no substantial links exist.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} In 2003, American terrorism analyst, [[Evan Kohlmann|Evan Kohlman]], said in an interview:
While there have been a number of promising intelligence leads hinting at possible meetings between al-Qaeda members and elements of the former [[Baghdad]] regime, nothing has been yet shown demonstrating that these potential contacts were historically any more significant than the same level of communication maintained between [[Osama bin Laden]] and ruling elements in a number of Iraq's [[Persian Gulf]] neighbors, including [[Saudi Arabia]], Iran, [[Yemen]], Qatar, and [[Kuwait]].{{cite web| last = Canellos| first = Peter S.| coauthors = and Bryan Bender| title = Questions Grow Over Iraq Links to Qaeda| publisher=CommonDreams.org| date = 3 August 2003| url = http://www.commondreams.org/headlines03/0803-04.htm| accessdate =6 December 2006 }}
In 2006, a report of postwar findings by the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] concluded that: {{quote|Postwar findings have identified only one meeting between representatives of al-Qa'ida and Saddam Hussein's regime reported in prewar intelligence assessments. Postwar findings have identified two occasions, not reported prior to the war, in which Saddam Hussein rebuffed meeting requests from an al-Qa'ida operative. The Intelligence Community has not found any other evidence of meetings between al'Qa'ida and Iraq.{{Cite web | title = Report of the Select Committee on Intelligence on Postwar Findings About Iraq's WMD Programs and Links to Terrorism and How They Compare With Prewar Assessments | publisher=[[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] | pages = 105 | date = 8 September 2006 | url = http://intelligence.senate.gov/phaseiiaccuracy.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =6 November 2010}}}} The same report also concluded that: {{quote|Saddam Hussein was distrustful of al-Qaeda and viewed Islamic extremists as a threat to his regime, refusing all requests from al-Qaeda to provide material or operational support.}} The result of the publication of the Senate report was the belief that the entire connection between Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda was an official deception based on [[Cherry picking (fallacy)|cherry picking]] specific intelligence data that bolstered the case for war with Iraq regardless of its reliability. One instance of this reaction was reported in a [[BBC]] news article, which stated: {{quote|Opposition Democrats are accusing the White House of deliberate deception. They say the revelation undermines the basis on which the US went to war in Iraq.{{cite news| title = Saddam 'had no link to al-Qaeda'|publisher=BBC News | date = 9 September 2006| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/5328592.stm| accessdate =6 December 2006 }}}} ==1988== * According to sworn testimony of al-Qaeda member Mohamed Rashed Daoud Al-'Owhali in 2001, Osama bin Laden delivered a lecture in Pakistan in 1988. During this lecture he spoke against Saddam Hussein and the [[Ba'ath party]] by warning his listeners about Saddam's expansionist ambitions in the Middle East.{{cite web | title = USA v. Usama Bin Laden â Trial Transcript Day 4 | publisher=[[Cryptome]] | date = 13 February 2001 | url = http://cryptome.org/usa-v-ubl-04.htm }} ==1990== ===March=== *During an interview with [[Peter Bergen]], Khaled Batarfi, and old friend of [[Osama bin Laden]], said that bin Laden had already predicted Saddam's invasion of Kuwait and had began preparations for war against Saddam. According to Batarfi, Bin Laden had said, "We should train our people, our young and increase our army and prepare for the day when eventually we are attacked. This guy [Saddam] can never be trusted." Batarfi himself went on to say about bin Laden: "He doesn't believe [Saddam] is a Muslim. So he never liked him nor trusted him."{{cite book | last = Bergen | first = Peter | title = The Osama bin Laden I Know: An Oral History of al Qaeda's Leader | publisher=Free Press | date = 8 August 2006 | location = New York City | pages = 111â112 | isbn = 0743278925}} ===2 August=== *Saddam Hussein's army invades Kuwait. In response to the perceived threat to Saudi Arabia, Osama bin Laden offers to bring an army of [[jihadist]] fighters to protect the kingdom against Saddam . The [[House of Saud|Saudi royal family]]'s decision to seek help from American troops rather than from bin Laden's jihadists is considered a turning point in bin Laden's life. The presence of American troops in the Arabian peninsula after the end of the [[Gulf War]] became, for bin Laden, a key piece of evidence that the U.S. was at war with [[Islam]]. Prince [[Turki bin Faisal Al Saud]], the former head of the Saudi intelligence agency [[Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah]], noted of bin Laden: "I saw radical changes in his personality as he changed from a calm, peaceful and gentle man interested in helping Muslims into a person who believed that he would be able to amass and command an army to liberate Kuwait. It revealed his arrogance."{{cite book | last = Bergen | first = Peter | title = The Osama bin Laden I Know: An Oral History of al Qaeda's Leader | publisher=Free Press | date = 8 August 2006 | location = New York City | pages = 112 | isbn = 0743278925}} *While bin Laden continued to oppose Saddam's Baathist government, he was also vocal in criticizing the [[Iraq sanctions|U.N. sanctions against Iraq]].{{cite book | last = Gunaratna | first = Rohan | title = Inside Al Qaeda: Global Network of Terror | publisher=Berkley Trade | date = 3 June 2003 | location = New York, NY | pages = 37 | isbn = 978-0425191149}} Bin Laden's bodyguard recalls that his intentions included not only the liberation of Kuwait but also "rescuing the Iraqi people from the domination of the Ba'th Party...Sheikh Osama bin Laden was dreaming of this." ==1992== * According to information that was first made public in the [[Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda link allegations#2003 Feith Report|Feith memo]], a meeting was arranged by [[Hassan al-Turabi]] between members of the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]] and members of al-Qaeda, allegedly with the goal of creating a common strategy for deposing pro-Western Arab governments. The American author [[Lawrence Wright]] comments in his [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning book ''[[The Looming Tower]]'' that: {{quote|The Iraqi delegation met with Bin Laden, even flattered him, claiming that he was the prophesied [[Mahdi]] the savior of Islam. They wanted him to stop backing anti-Saddam insurgents, Bin Laden agreed. But in return he asked for weapons and training camps inside Iraq. That same year, [[Ayman al-Zawahiri]] traveled to Bagdad where he met Saddam Hussein in person. But there is no evidence that Iraq ever supplied al-Qaeda with weapons or camps, and soon bin Laden resumed his support of Iraqi dissidents."{{cite book | last = Wright | first = Lawrence | title = The Looming Tower | publisher=Knopf | year = 2006 | pages = 295â296 | isbn = 978-0375414862}}}} ==1993== *The [[1993 World Trade Center bombing]] occurred on 26 February. One of the conspirators was [[Abdul Rahman Yasin]], an American of Iraqi descent born in [[Bloomington]], [[Indiana]]. After the attack he fled to Iraq where he allegedly moved in with a relative and received support from the Iraqi government.{{cite news| last = Diamond| first = John| title = U.S.: Iraq sheltered suspect in '93 WTC attack|work=USA Today | date = 27 September 2003| url = http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/iraq/2003-09-17-iraq-wtc_x.htm| accessdate =6 December 2006 }}{{cite web | author=Web Editor | title = Abdul Rahman Yasin | publisher=National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC) | url = http://www.nctc.gov/site/profiles/yasin.htm | accessdate =22 November 2007 | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071109063701/http://www.nctc.gov/site/profiles/yasin.htm| archivedate = 9 November 2007}} *The Iraqi government claimed they imprisoned Yasin in 1994, where he remained until at least 2002.[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/05/31/60minutes/main510795.shtml 60 Minutes: The Man Who Got Away, Says '93 WTC Bombers Originally Targeted Jewish Neighborhoods â CBS News] at www.cbsnews.com Iraq made an offer to the Clinton Administration to trade Yasin in 1998, but the Clinton administration rejected the offer.{{cite web| last = Strobel| first = Warren P.| coauthors = Jonathan S. Landay and John Walcott| title = Doubts Cast on Efforts to Link Saddam, al-Qaida | publisher=CommonDreams.org| date = 3 March 2004| url = http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/0303-01.htm| accessdate =7 December 2006 }} The Iraqis made a similar offer to the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]] in 2003 but this offer was also spurned.{{cite web| last = Risen| first = James| title = Iraq Said to Have Tried to Reach Last-Minute Deal to Avert War| publisher=CommonDreams.org| date = 6 November 2003| url = http://www.commondreams.org/headlines03/1106-02.htm| accessdate =7 December 2006 }} An anonymous intelligence official claimed that Iraq required the U.S. to sign a statement discussing Yasin's whereabouts that was at odds with the U.S. "version of the facts." Former Iraqi foreign minister [[Tariq Aziz]], however, claimed that the offers were made without conditions.{{cite news| first = | title = US 'refused Iraq's terror suspect offer|publisher=BBC | date = 20 June 2002| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/2022991.stm | accessdate =22 November 2007 }} The same Intelligence official stated that the Iraqi's wanted the US to "sign a lengthy document that included information about Yasin's whereabouts since 1993, and how they had tried to Turn him over. "We refused to sign," said the official, "Because we believe their version was inaccurate." The US, he said, offered to sign a simple receipt acknowledging that the Iraqis had turned Yasin over to us. But they did not respond."{{cite web | last = Editor | first = CBS Web Site | title = Transcript: The Yasin Interview: A 60 Minutes Exclusive |publisher=CBS | date = not provided | accessdate =24 November 2007 |url=? }} *Neil Herman, who headed the [[FBI]] investigation into the 1993 World Trade Center attack, noted that despite Yasin's presence in Baghdad, there was no evidence of Iraqi support for the attack. "We looked at that rather extensively," he told CNN terrorism analyst [[Peter Bergen]]. "There were no ties to the Iraqi government." Bergen writes:
In sum, by the mid-'90s, the [[Joint Terrorism Task Force]] in New York, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|F.B.I.]], the [[United States Attorney|U.S. Attorney]]'s office in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|Southern District of New York]], the [[Central Intelligence Agency|C.I.A.]], the [[United States National Security Council|N.S.C.]], and the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] had all found no evidence implicating the Iraqi government in the first Trade Center attack."{{cite web| last = Bergen| first = Peter| title = Armchair Provocateur â Laurie Mylroie: The Neocons' favorite conspiracy theorist.| publisher=Washington Monthly| month = December | year = 2003| url = http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2003/0312.bergen.html| accessdate =7 December 2006 }}
*During the [[9/11 Commission]] Hearings, former U.S. counterterrorism chief [[Richard A. Clarke]] was asked about whether Yasin going to Iraq established a connection between Saddam Hussein and the 1993 World Trade Center attack. His response was unequivocating:
But the investigation, both the CIA investigation and the FBI investigation, made it very clear in '95 and '96 as they got more information, that the Iraqi government was in no way involved in the attack. And the fact that one of the 12 people involved in the attack was Iraqi hardly seems to me as evidence that the Iraqi government was involved in the attack. The attack was al-Qaida; not Iraq. The Iraqi government because, obviously, of the hostility between us and them, didn't cooperate in turning him over and gave him sanctuary, as it did give sanctuary to other terrorists. But the allegation that has been made that the 1993 attack on the World Trade Center was done by the Iraqi government I think is absolutely without foundation.{{cite news| title = Wednesday's 9/11 Commission Hearings| work=transcript|work=Washington Post | date =24 March 2004| url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A20349-2004Mar24.html| accessdate =7 December 2006 }}
==1994== *[[Farouk Hijazi]], former head of the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]], allegedly meets with [[Osama bin Laden]] in Sudan. Former [[CIA]] [[counter-terrorism]] official [[Vincent Cannistraro]] claimed that bin Laden rejected Hijazi's overtures, and concluded that bin Laden did not want to be "exploited" by Iraq's [[Secularity|secular]] regime.{{cite web| last = Isikoff| first = Michael| coauthors = and Mark Hosenball| title = Case Decidedly Not Closed|work=Newsweek | date = 19 November 2003| url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3540586/| accessdate =6 December 2006 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061109194327/http://msnbc.msn.com/id/3540586/ |archivedate = 9 November 2006}} According to ''[[The Guardian]]'':
Most analysts believe, however, that the ideological differences between the Iraqis and the terrorists were insurmountable. It is thought that bin Laden rejected any kind of alliance, preferring to pursue his own policy of global [[jihad]], or holy war.{{cite news| last = Bright| first = Martin| coauthors = and Jason Burke| title = Saddam 'held talks on alliance with al-Qaeda'|work=The Guardian |location=UK | date = 27 April 2003| url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/alqaida/story/0,12469,944589,00.html| accessdate =6 December 2006 }}
==1995== ===19 February, Sudan=== *A handwritten note that is a part of the [[Operation Iraqi Freedom documents]] collection (released by the U.S. government in 2006) suggests that a representative of Saddam's government met with bin Laden in Sudan on 19 February 1995. According to the note, bin laden suggested "carrying out joint operations against foreign forces" in Saudi Arabia. *An [[ABC News]] article, which reported on the document, notes that eight months after the date of this document, al Qaeda staged an attack in [[Riyadh]]. Neither ABC nor any other source has offered information suggesting that Iraq participated in planning these attacks, and the Iraqi government has never been accused of such participation{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}, and ABC notes that the militants who attacked the facility "later confessed on Saudi TV to having been trained by Osama bin Laden." The ABC article further notes that "the document does not establish that the two parties did in fact enter into an operational relationship," and also that the contacts may have "been approved personally by Saddam Hussein." The ABC article also cautions that "this document is handwritten and has no official seal."{{cite web| title = Did Russian Ambassador Give Saddam the U.S. War Plan?| publisher=ABC News| date = 23 March 2006| url = http://abcnews.go.com/International/IraqCoverage/story?id=1734490&page=1| accessdate =7 December 2006 }} *CNN terrorism expert Peter Bergen commented, "The results of this meeting were ... nothing. Two subsequent attacks against American forces in Saudi Arabia â a car bombing that year and the [[Khobar Towers]] attack in 1996 â were carried out, respectively, by locals who said they were influenced by Mr. bin Laden and by the Saudi branch of [[Hezbollah]], a [[Shia Islam|Shiite]] group aided by [[Iran]]ian government officials."{{cite news| last = Bergen| first = Peter| title = Enemy of Our Enemy| work=op-ed| publisher=NY Times| date = 28 March 2006| url = http://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/28/opinion/28bergen.html?ex=1165640400&en=fdde05968a5e2c68&ei=5070| accessdate =7 December 2006 }} Registration required. *The ''[[New York Times]]'' reported that a "joint intelligence task force" concluded that the document "appeared authentic". The document, which asserts that bin Laden "was approached by our side," states that bin Laden previously "had some reservations about being labeled an Iraqi operative," but was willing to meet in Sudan. At the meeting, bin Laden requested that sermons of an anti-Saudi cleric be rebroadcast in Iraq. That request, the document states, was approved by Baghdad. The document also states that Iraqi intelligence officers began "seeking other channels through which to handle the relationship, in light of [bin Laden's departure from Sudan]". The Iraqi document states that "cooperation between the two organizations should be allowed to develop freely through discussion and agreement."{{cite news| last = Shanker| first = Thom| title = Iraqis, Seeking Foes of Saudis, Contacted bin Laden, File Says| publisher=NY Times| date = 25 June 2004| url = http://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/25/politics/25TERR.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5007&en=d9a3d1aa68140e2c&ex=1403496000&partner=USERLAND| accessdate =7 December 2006 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Registration required. ===September, Sudan=== *[[Brigadier]] Salim al-Ahmed, a top explosives expert of the Iraqi Intelligence Service (IIS), allegedly met with bin Laden in [[Khartoum]], Sudan, in SeptemberâOctober 1995.{{cite news | last = Phillips | first = Melanie | title = There was a link between Saddam and al-Qa'eda | work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | date = 20 June 2004 | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3607455/There-was-a-link-between-Saddam-and-al-Qaeda.html | accessdate =18 November 2010 | location=London}} According to the 9/11 Commission Report:
At least one of these reports dates the meeting to 1994, but other evidence indicates the meeting may have occurred in February 1995.{{cite book | title = The 9/11 Commission Report | date = 22 July 2004 | pages = 468 | url = http://govinfo.library.unt.edu/911/report/911Report.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =18 November 2010}}
* A second meeting between the IIS and bin Laden is alleged to have taken place in Sudan, in July 1996. At this meeting, Mani' Abd Rashid al-Tikriti, a director of the IIS, was allegedly present. According to the 9/11 Commission report, however, the veracity of the second meeting is in doubt due to the [[anachronism]] of events:
The information is puzzling, since bin Ladin left Sudan for Afghanistan in May 1996, and there is no evidence he ventured back there (or anywhere else) for a visit. In examining the source material, the reports note that the information was received 'third hand,' passed from the foreign government service that 'does not meet directly with the ultimate source of the information, but obtains the information from him through two unidentified intermediaries, one of whom merely delivers the information to the Service.'" The same source also claims al-Ahmed was seen near bin Laden's farm in December 1995.
===Starting in 1995, Salman Pak, Iraq=== * Several Iraqi defectors report that hundreds of foreign terrorists were being trained in [[Aircraft hijacking|airplane hijacking]] techniques "without weapons" using a real airplane (variously reported as a [[Boeing 707]] and a [[Tupolev Tu-154]]) as a [[Theatrical property|prop]] at [[Salman Pak facility|Salman Pak]], an Iraqi military facility just south of Baghdad, between 1995 and 2000. The training program was allegedly run by the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]], i.e., the Mukhabarat.{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/gunning/interviews/khodada.html |title=Frontline: Gunning for Saddam: Interviews: Sabah Khodada |publisher=PBS |accessdate=7 July 2009}} This allegation has also been reported by the following defectors: ** Sabah Khalifa Khodada Alami (former Iraqi army captain), who provided details of the layout of the camp as early as 1998 ** "Abu Zeinab" al-Ghurairy (former Iraqi sergeant who claimed to be a general), who corroborated Khodada's details in 2000 ** [[Khidir Hamza]], a scientist who worked on Iraq's nuclear program{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/gunning/interviews/hamza.html |title=Frontline: Gunning for Saddam: Interviews: Khidir Hamza |publisher=PBS |date=8 November 2001 |accessdate=7 July 2009}} ** Abdul Rahman al-Shamari, a Mukhabarat agent in U.S. custody ** "Abu Mohammed", a former colonel in [[Fedayeen Saddam]]{{cite web | last = Roberts | first = Gwynne | title = Baghdad Trained Al Qaeda Fighters in Chemical Warfare | work=Daily Times | date = 15 July 2002 | url = http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_15-7-2002_pg4_ | accessdate =2 December 2010}} * The credibility of Khodada and Abu Zeinab is often questioned, however, due to their association with the [[Iraqi National Congress]], an organization that has been accused of deliberately supplying false information to the U.S. government in order to build support for regime change.{{cite web | last1 = Landay | first1 = Jonathan S. | last2 = Wells | first2 = Tish | title = Global Misinformation Campaign was Used to Build Case for War | work=CommonDreams.org | date = 16 March 2004 | url = http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/0316-02.htm | accessdate =2 December 2010}} According to Helen Kennedy of the ''[[New York Daily News]]''
The INCâs agenda was to get us into a war. The really damaging stories all came from those guys, not the CIA. They did a really sophisticated job of getting it out there.[http://www.cjr.org/issues/2004/4/mccollam-list.asp CJR July/August 2004: The List by Douglas McCollam]{{Dead link|date=July 2009}}
One of the defectors, al-Ghurairy, has been described as "a complete fake â a low-ranking former soldier whom [[Ahmed Chalabi]]'s aides had coached to deceive the media."{{cite web | last = Fairweather | first = Jack | title = Heroes in Error | work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | date = March/April 2006 | url = http://motherjones.com/politics/2006/03/heroes-error | accessdate =2 December 2010}} Another defector who interviewed al-Ghurairy noted, "He is an opportunist, cheap and manipulative. He has poetic interests and has a vivid imagination in making up stories."{{cite web | last = Dwyer | first = Jim | title = Defectors' Reports on Iraq Arms Were Embellished, Exile Asserts | work=Information Clearing House | date = 9 July 2004 | url = http://www.informationclearinghouse.info/article6455.htm | accessdate =2 December 2010}} Inconsistencies in the stories of the defectors led U.S. officials, journalists, and investigators to conclude that the Salman Pak story was inaccurate. One senior U.S. official said that they had found "nothing to substantiate" the claim that al-Qaeda trained at Salman Pak other than the testimony of several INC defectors. * Saddam's government had even denied that an airplane existed 25 kilometers southeast of Baghdad. The Iraqi ambassador to the U.N., Mohammed Aldouri, told ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' in the fall of 2001,
I am lucky that I know the area, this Salman Pak. This is a very beautiful area with gardens, with trees. It is not possible to do such a program there, because there's no place for planes.{{cite web | last = Carson | first = Christopher S. | title = An Unapologetic Apology | work=National Review | date = 2 June 2004 | url = http://old.nationalreview.com/comment/carson200406020845.asp | accessdate =2 December 2010}}
* The chief of the [[Iraq Survey Group]], [[Charles Duelfer]], however, expressed a different opinion about Salman Pak in 2001: "We always just called them the terrorist camps. We reported them at the time, but they've obviously taken on new significance.".{{cite news | last = Eisler | first = Peter | title = U.S. Officials Question Link Between 9/11 and Iraq |work=USA Today | date = 2 December 2001 | url = http://www.usatoday.com/news/sept11/2001/12/03/1acover.htm | accessdate =2 December 2010}} He also said that the Iraqis told the [[United Nations Special Commission]] (UNSCOM) that the Salman Pak facility was used by police for counter-terrorist training.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} "Of course we automatically took out the word 'counter'," Duelfer explained.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} Furthermore, after the [[Iraq War|invasion of Iraq]], the camp was captured by [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marines]] "after it was discussed by Egyptian and Sudanese fighters caught elsewhere in Iraq."{{cite news | title = Jet Shell Reinforces Suspicions About Terrorist Training |agency=Associated Press | date = 7 April 2003 | url = http://www.sptimes.com/2003/04/07/Worldandnation/Jet_shell_reinforces_.shtml | accessdate =2 December 2010}}{{cite web | last = Murdock | first = Deroy | title = At Salman Pak | work=National Review | date = 7 April 2003 | url = http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/206485/salman-pak/deroy-murdock | accessdate =2 December 2010}} Brigadier General Vincent Brooks described the capture, saying,
The nature of the work being done by some of those people that we captured, their inferences to the type of training that they received, all of these things give us the impression that there was terrorist training that was conducted at Salman Pak.
The independent Iraqi weekly ''Al-Yawm Al-Aakher'' interviewed a former Iraqi officer who also claimed that Salman Pak was being used to train foreign terrorists.{{cite web | title = Iraqi Daily: Saddam Ordered Training of Al-Qa'ida Members | work=The Middle East Media Research Institute (MEMRI) | date = 17 October 2003 | url = http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/974.htm | accessdate =2 December 2010}} * The investigative journalist Seymour Hersh, however, expresses an opposite stance in noting that
Salman Pak was overrun by American troops on 6 April [2003]. Apparently, neither the camp nor the former biological facility has yielded evidence to substantiate the claims made before the war [that the camp was used for terrorist training].{{cite web|last=Hersh |first=Seymour M. |url=http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/?030512fa_fact |title=Annals of National Security: Selective Intelligence: The New Yorker |work=The New Yorker |date=7 January 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2009}}{{Dead link|date=December 2010}}
A similar view is also held by Douglas MacCollam, a journalist for the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'',
There still remain claims and counterclaims about what was going on at Salman Pak. But the consensus view now is that the camp was what Iraq told UN weapons inspectors it was â a counterterrorism training camp for army commandos.
* In the Senate Intelligence Committeeâs 2006 report, the DIA stated that it found "no credible reports that non-Iraqis were trained to conduct or support transnational terrorist operations at Salman Pak after 1991." Explaining the origins for the false allegations, the DIA concluded that [[Operation Desert Storm]] had brought attention to the training base at Salman Pak, so
Fabricators and unestablished sources who reported hearsay or third-hand information created a large volume of human intelligence reporting. This type of reporting surged after September 2001.{{cite web | last = Parry | first = Robert | title = How Neocon Favorites Duped U.S. | work=The Baltimore Chronicle & Sentinel | date = 1 November 2006 | url = http://baltimorechronicle.com/2006/110106Parry.shtml | accessdate =2 December 2010}}
===Circa 1995, Iraq=== * An al-Qaeda operative using the alias Abu Abdullah al-Iraqi allegedly requests help in chemical weapons training from Saddam. The request was supposedly approved and trainers from Unit 999, an Iraqi secret-police organization organized by [[Uday Hussein]], were dispatched to camps in Afghanistan.{{cite web | last = Goldberg | first = Jeffery | title = The Unknown: The C.I.A. and the Pentagon take another look at Al Qaeda and Iraq |work=The New Yorker | date = 10 February 2003 | url = http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2003/02/10/030210fa_fact | accessdate =18 November 2010}} Two U.S. counter-terrorism officials told ''[[Newsweek]]'' that they believe the information about al-Iraqi came exclusively from the captured al-Qaeda operative [[Ibn al-Shaykh al-Libi]], who has since recanted, and whose credibility was impugned by both the CIA and the [[Defense Intelligence Agency]] (DIA).{{cite web|url=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/9991919/site/newsweek/ |title=New CIA Paper Shows Pre-War Intel Flaws - Newsweek National News |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=7 July 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} * A DIA report in February 2002 concluded:
This is the first report from Ibn al-Shaykh in which he claims Iraq assisted al-Qaidaâs CBRN [Chemical, Biological, Radiological or Nuclear] efforts. However, he lacks specific details on the Iraqis involved, the CBRN materials associated with the assistance, and the location where training occurred. It is possible he does not know any further details; it is more likely this individual is intentionally misleading the debriefers. Ibn al-Shaykh has been undergoing debriefs for several weeks and may be describing scenarios to the debriefers that he knows will retain their interest.{{cite web | last = Turner | first = Kathleen, P. | title = DIA letter regarding al-Libi | publisher=Defense Intelligence Agency | date = 26 October 2005 | url = http://levin.senate.gov/newsroom/supporting/2005/DIAletter.102605.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =18 November 2010}}
* A CIA report in January 2003 voiced similar concerns, also noting that al-Libi was "not in a position to know" the things he had told interrogators. The CIA recalled all of its intelligence reports that were based on al-Libi's testimony in February 2004. * It was revealed in December 2005 that al-Libi lied about this, and other, information regarding Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda in order to avoid harsh treatment by his [[Egypt]]ian captors, to whom he had been transferred under the controversial American policy of [[extraordinary rendition]].{{cite news | first=Douglas | last=Jehl | title=Qaeda-Iraq Link U.S. Cited Is Tied to Coercion Claim | date=9 December 2005 |work=New York Times | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/09/politics/09intel.html | accessdate=5 August 2008}} ==1997== * On 7 December 1997, in a meeting between U.S. and [[Taliban]] officials, the Taliban's acting Minister of Mines and Industry, Armad Jan, tells the U.S. [[Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs]], [[Karl Inderfurth]], that the Taliban "had frustrated Iranian and Iraqi efforts to contact" bin Laden.{{cite web | title = Memo shows Iraq, Iran tried to contact bin Laden |work=The Washington Times | date = 12 September 2003 | url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2003/sep/12/20030912-012437-3992r | accessdate =18 November 2010}} Inderfurth, however, disagreed with this claim, and told ''[[The Washington Times]]'', "I never saw any evidence in anything I was doing where there were any Iraqi connections." The same article also reported that:
Mr. Inderfurth said he did not believe the Taliban claim was credible at the time, and that he had no recollection of Taliban officials mentioning Iraqi or Iranian attempts to meet bin Laden in the following 19 meetings he would attend with the de facto Afghan regime for the next four years.
==1998== ===Circa 1998, Baghdad=== [[Ayman al-Zawahiri]], Al-Qaeda second-in-command, allegedly meets [[Taha Yasin Ramadan]], Iraqi vice-president.{{cite news | title=Who's who in Iraq | date=6 August 2002 |work=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2174293.stm | accessdate=5 August 2008 | first=Paul | last=Reynolds}} The source of this unlikely claim appears to be [[Yossef Bodansky]]'s controversial book published in 1999, ''Bin Laden: The Man Who Declared War on America'' (p. 322), which makes many similar unsourced claims. "This was a red-team effort," he said. "We looked at this as an opportunity to disprove the conventional wisdom, and basically we came to the conclusion that the CIA had this one right." He further stated that
No one disputes that there have been contacts over the years. In that part of the America-hating universe, contacts happen. But that's still a long way from suggesting that they were really working together.{{cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines03/0803-04.htm |title=Questions Grow Over Iraq Links to Qaeda |publisher=Commondreams.org |accessdate=7 July 2009}}
===23 February, Afghanistan=== Osama bin Laden issues a [[FatwÄ|fatwa]] urging jihad against all Americans. In his fatwa, bin Laden states
The ruling to kill the Americans and their allies â civilians and military â is an individual duty for every Muslim who can do it in any country in which it is possible to do it, in order to liberate the al-Aqsa Mosque and the holy mosque [Mecca] from their grip, and in order for their armies to move out of all the lands of Islam, defeated and unable to threaten any Muslim.
He also states that one of his reasons for the fatwa is the "Americans' continuing aggression against the Iraqi people." Bin Laden mentions aggression against Iraq four times in the fatwa. A more important reason is the perceived American aggression against Muslims, which is mentioned seven times.{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/terrorism/international/fatwa_1998.html |title=Online NewsHour: Al Qaeda's 1998 Fatwa | publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] |date=23 February 1998 | accessdate=7 December 2010}} ===March, Baghdad=== *According to Inigo Gilmore of London's ''Telegraph'', the Iraqi Intelligence Service, i.e., the Mukhabarat, arranged for an envoy from bin Laden to travel from Sudan to Baghdad to meet with Iraqi officials. Gilmore's claim is based on three stapled pages that he claims to have found in the Mukhabarat headquarters in early 2003, which he smuggled out of the building while it was guarded by American troops. Gilmore stated that the CIA had already been through the building for intelligence "but they seem to have missed this particular document."{{cite news | title=Iraq files 'show al-Qaeda link' | date=27 April 2003 |work=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2979405.stm | accessdate=25 December 2010}} *According to the handwritten documents, the Al-Qaeda envoy stayed at the al-Mansour Melia, a first class hotel. A letter with this document states that the envoy was a trusted confidant of bin Laden. It also reads
According to the above, we suggest permission to call the Khartoum station [Iraq's intelligence office in Sudan] to facilitate the travel arrangements for the above-mentioned person to Iraq. And that our body carry all the travel and hotel costs inside Iraq to gain the knowledge of the message from bin Laden and to convey to his envoy an oral message from us to bin Laden.
The letter refers to al-Qaeda's leader as an opponent of the Saudi Arabian regime and says that the message to be conveyed to bin Laden through the envoy "would relate to the future of our relationship with him, bin Laden, and to achieve a direct meeting with him." The meeting was allegedly extended by a week and the document "recommends contacts with bin Laden."{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2003%2F04%2F27%2Fwalq27.xml |title=The proof that Saddam worked with bin Laden â Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph |accessdate=7 July 2009 | location=London |first=Peter |last=Oborne}} *Based on these documents the ''Telegraph'' stated that these "Iraqi intelligence documents discovered in Baghdad by The Telegraph have provided the first evidence of a direct link between Osama bin Laden's al-Qa'eda terrorist network and Saddam Hussein's regime." *According to the ''Observer'', however, these Baghdad talks "are thought to have ended disastrously for the Iraqis, as bin Laden rejected any kind of alliance, preferring to pursue his own policy of global jihad.".{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/alqaida/story/0,12469,944589,00.html |title=Saddam 'held talks on alliance with al-Qaeda' , Special reports , Guardian Unlimited |work=Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=7 July 2009 | date=27 April 2003 | first=Martin | last=Bright}} ===August, Khartoum=== * U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] orders eighty [[Tomahawk (missile)|Tomahawk missiles]] fired at targets in Afghanistan and Sudan, including the [[Al-Shifa pharmaceutical factory]]. The Clinton Administration claimed the factory was actually a [[chemical weapons]] plant operated by al-Qaeda. *Clinton's [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[William Cohen]] would testify to the [[9/11 Commission]] in 2004 that intelligence officials suspected "indirect links between the facility and bin Laden and the Iraqi chemical weapons program." He also noted that
The direct physical evidence from the scene obtained at that time convinced the U.S. intelligence community that their suspicions were correct about the facilityâs chemical weapons role and that there was a risk of chemical agents getting into the hands of al-Qaeda.{{cite web | last = Cohen | first = William S. | title = Statement of William S. Cohen to The National Commission On Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States | work=2004 Congressional Hearings | publisher=[[Federation of American Scientists]] | date = 24 March 2004 | url = http://www.fas.org/irp/congress/2004_hr/cohen_statement.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =25 December 2010}}

the evidence that prompted President Clinton to order the missile strike on the Shifa plant was not as solid as first portrayed. Sudan Says, 'Say Sorry,' but U.S. Won't | date=20 October 2005 |work=New York Times | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/20/international/africa/20khartoum.html | accessdate=5 August 2008 | first=Marc | last=Lacey}}

Now, the analysts renewed their doubts and told Assistant Secretary of State [[Phyllis E. Oakley|Phyllis Oakley]] that the C.I.A.'s evidence on which the attack was based was inadequate. So far, the U.S. has refused the invitation to investigate and also to officially apologize for the attacks, suggesting that some still privately suspect that chemical weapons activity existed there. ===August, Pakistan=== Stephen Hayes of the ''[[Weekly Standard]]'' reported that this month, according to a "Summary of Evidence" released by the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] in March 2005 concerning a detainee held at the [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]], that this former [[infantry]]man of the [[Iraqi Army]] who became an al-Qaeda agent traveled to Pakistan with a member of Iraqi intelligence "for the purpose of blowing up the Pakistan, United States and British Embassies with chemical mortars."{{cite web | last = Hayes | first = Stephen F. | last2 = Joscelyn | first2 = Thomas | title = The Mother of All Connections | work=The Weekly Standard | date = 18 July 2005 | url = http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/005/804yqqnr.asp | accessdate =25 December 2010}} An [[Associated Press]] report of the same document, however, includes the caveat

===18 or 21 December, Afghanistan=== *The Iraqi ambassador to Turkey, [[Farouk Hijazi]], allegedly meets with bin Laden in Afghanistan.{{cite news | last = Borger | first = Julian | title = Saddam link to Bin Laden | work=The Guardian | date = 6 February 1999 | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/1999/feb/06/julianborger | accessdate =25 December 2010 | location=London}} An article that appeared in the''[[Corriere della Sera]],'' a newspaper published in [[Milan]], was translated by the CIA and read
